Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2009 08:06PM Debonthelake wrote: Hi, Deb My genetic testing is complete.  My family history includes my mother who had ER+ breast cancer 15 years ago,  my father who died last spring of an unusually aggressive form of prostate cancer, two of his brothers had breast cancer and my father's mother died of either ovarian or uterine cancer when she was 62 years old.  I was definitely a candidate for BRACA testing.  Ovarian cancer is very frightening it is called the silent killer because it goes undetected so long.  I'm still in shock because my BRACA testing was negative.  My oncologist tells me that this means that I am no more likely to get ovarian cancer than the general public and only slightly more likely to get breast cancer again.   Like Eldub there is a part of me that wishes it were positive so that there was a clear plan of action.  I'm glad to keep my boobs and it's nice not having surgery ahead of me.  I don't think the insurance will cover any more surgery on me at this time. LRM216 In order for many insurance companies to cover your BRACA testing you have to have a pretty significant history of certain cancers.  Breast, ovarian and prostate cancers are included. That's my two cents and what little information I've gleaned so far about that. God Bless
Posts.Title: BRCA testing deb6563 tweekerbeeker

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2009 04:43PM Debonthelake wrote: I had 33 rad treatments.  I had chemo prior to rads.  Early during rads I often took 3 hour naps and also slept 8-10 hours through the night.  I worked hard at getting regular exercise and eating well.  Each week of rads I felt a little better.  After a month of rads I was informed I was no longer anemic.  It turns out a lot of my fatigue was a post chemo reaction.  I've been done with rads for a month now.  I feel pretty good.  Really long 10 hour work days get to me a bit more than they did prior to breast cancer but other than that I feel really well.
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2009 07:36PM Debonthelake wrote: The not knowing and the what if's are the most difficult part.  I wish for you health and that your results will be B-9.  I'm just glad that you could get over your shyness enough to seek attention.  If it's not B-9 early detection is important.  I'm not going to say that being treated for cancer is fun but, this is a curable disease.  God Bless you Deb
Posts.Title: Who Knew??? Trabby Debonthelake

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2009 09:59PM Debonthelake wrote: Dear Sparrow, I remember the shock of my early diagnosis.  It's such a shock and so terrifying.  I remember feeling so vulnerable and afraid.  But, I've had loved ones who have gone before me and It helped me to remind myself of the breast cancer survivors who have gone before me.  My Mom was diagnosed and treated 15 years ago and she is doing well.   It is best just to take it one step at a time.  There is a lot to learn but, everyones diagnosis is a bit different and treatment options and approaches vary.   Those early days are the worst.  Once you get the information that you need and you collaborate with your doctor for a game plan your fight begins.  The action of fighting the disease is much easier than the waiting. I have been through a lumpectomy, chemo and radiation.  My treatment is behind me now except for good diet and exercise.  It is a good place to be.  My prayers are with you.  God Bless you Deb
Posts.Title: I just can't deal with this Sparrow one-L
